conclusion: The problem involves analyzing forces acting on a block and a plank to determine the condition under which the plank moves upward.

The plank has a length of 0.60 m and mass of 0.40 kg, while the block has a mass of 0.80 kg. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the plank is 0.20, and the maximum static friction equals the kinetic friction.
The forces acting on the block are: horizontal force F1, vertical force F2, frictional force f, and gravitational force mg.
The block is initially at rest, and the goal is to make the plank move upward by analyzing the net forces acting on the block.
To make the plank move upward, the block must accelerate upward, requiring the net force on the block to be upward.
The net force on the block is the sum of F1, F2, and the frictional force f.
F1 is the only force acting to the left, so it must be greater than the frictional force f to cause the block to accelerate.
F2 is the only force acting upward, so it must be greater than the frictional force f to cause the block to accelerate upward.
The condition for the plank to move upward is that F1 must be greater than the frictional force f.
The frictional force f is given by the equation f = μmg.
Substituting the given values into f = μmg, we calculate f = 0.20 × 0.80 × 10 = 1.6 N.
The condition for the plank to move upward is that F1 must be greater than 1.6 N.
